comment_0:
Finally, 10 years later, some clarification from the band!

If you listen to A Perfect Circle's "Judith" and more importantly, Tool's new "10,000 days (Wings for Marie Part 2)", most is explained.

His mothers name was Judith Marie Keenan.
in Judith, Maynard sings 'fuck your god, he's the one that left you broken down and paralyzed'.
In 10,000 days, he sings '10,000 days in the fire is long enough, you're going home', 'Judith Marie, unconditional one'.

Judith Marie suffered for 10,000 days, perhaps from a stroke that left her paralyzed?
She died on 18 June 2003. Maynard was born on 17 April 1964, so he was 39.2. 10,000 days is 27.4 years.
39.2 - 27.4 = 11.8. He was 11 years old when it happened.

Like Jimmy, the track 10,000 days also refers to "holding the light" and the light leading you home. In this track, the light is her gift of guidance and faith in him. Home is heaven.

Therefore I think Jimmy is about Maynard losing his mother as he knew her. He was young and depended on her. "The face of your own stability".  He talks to/of himself (jimmy, eleven) in third person as he is no longer the innocent child he was prior to this event. 
Half way through the song, "So glad that I have found you" is Jimmy realising that he himself is lost, not her. The person he knew is still with him in the form of the gift of guidance (the light or "loaded memory") she has instilled in him, and he goes on to use it to lead a successful life.
"I am wide awake and headed home". There's an ongoing theme in Tool about pain being necessary to advance, and life being that step (best example is Parabol). "Heading home" means living his life, moving forward towards the afterlife. "as soon as pain allows" means as soon as he has learned the lessons of life.
"So we can reunite, and both move on together". Maybe the song is about them reuniting back to the state of happy memories, when they become "one" in the afterlife. There's also an ongoing theme of collective consciousness through much of Tools work.

Anyway, my main point being that Tool's new work surely confirms "he" is mjk and "she" is jmk.

The song is about spiritual growth, as achieved through overcoming painful events that have been put into Maynard's life path.  

"til one and one are one, eleven.."  means 1 and 1 together make 11. In numerology and spirituality 11 is a 'master' number.  this means that someone who's life is lead by the number 11 has the opportunity to achieve spiritual mastery and move on from this plane of existence upon death. Maynard is talking about gaining insight into the pain of his past, his childhood. "glow child glow" means that his childhood will lead him back home. Home being the place beyond, the great light.

It's also worth knowing that individuals whose lives are governed by 11 are believed to be spiritual 'messengers'.  In many cases they are artists and spiritual leaders.

The general content of the album deals with spiritual growth, for example the song "third eye".  Look into what third eye means if you are interested.

comment_6:
It seems that Maynard is referring to his eleven year-old self in this song (calling him simply "Eleven").  Something was lost in Maynard when his mother experienced her aneurysm: a part of Maynard stopped growing with him and moving on.  This is evidenced by the lyrics;  "Eleven is standing still,"; and, "Eleven has been and will be waiting."  

For whatever reason, Maynard needed to go home to "reunite" with that lost part of him.  Perhaps it is the part of him that looked to his mother as his "stability" or just as someone to share mutual care and love for.  Eleven may be the part of him thats capable of loving his mother unconditionally: of idolizing and adoring her the way young children tend to; but that post age eleven, he moved on with the realization of his mother's mortality and may have been angered by it. It does seem that he's grown more compassionate and understanding towards her throughout his songs about her over the years. He might be seeking the balance between loving her as a young child does, but accepting her mortality and that what happened was beyond her control.  Going home seems like a good place to do so if thats where his mother was. 

Just a guess though, as I'll never know exactly how he felt towards his mother before, during or after this song (or any of them for that matter).

comment_74:
Treebeard says a story is only worth telling if it takes a long time to tell (or something like that)

Here's what I think...
Nailbunny and the first two paragraphs of Rog27's sub sum it up well (Rog does unfold his portable soap-box and go on a bit of a rant in the last bit...)

But I can read other interpretations in it, too.  The narrator (i.e. Keenan), might be describing a painful event at an early age, or we could even go so far as to say that Keenan is lamenting the (for want of better words) 'separation of his spirit', around the age of 11.

As a child, he was a 'perfect spirit' (and please don't mistake me for a crushed-purple-velvet-wearing, palm-reading, chrystal-giggling clairvouyant) as a child, complete; innocent.  His loss was not a literal one, but a spiritual and psychological one.  As he grew/grows into a man, he loses his feminine aspect, or his anima.

No, I didn't misspell aenima, the anima is roughly, in the terms of analytical psychology (founded by Carl Jung and distinct from psychoanalysis, founded by Sigmund Freud, who Jung was mentored by) the female aspect of any male.  i guess it goes along the argument that we are not 100% MALE, but only the majority of our genes/physiology and mental processes are male.  females have a male-aspect, too, and Jung calls this the animus.  Web search these words, there's tonnes of stuff out there.

So our little jimmy is growing into a big James, he's becoming a man, he's losing that unique, androgenous state that we all have as kids (more or less).  The narrator is quite obviously the man that jimmy has become.  He is the lead singer of Tool and he's more than dabbled in the occult, mystical, spiritual etc. endeavours of other people.  He's read a tonne of Jung's work (and stated as much in interviews) and he's aware that Jung talks about the chymical marriage, or reunion.  It follows the lines of the alchemical process (I think), which is the black, white, yellow, red stuff in Lateralus.  The chymical reunion (see the 'Art' card in Aleister Crowley Thoth tarot cards - again, web search it), is the joining of the king and the queen, or rather crudely, Keenan trying to 'reunite' with this anima, to become 'One' again.

It's not an easy process; the negredo, albedo, rubedo parts of alchemy involve a lot of soul-searching, self-exploration and -realisation, and, possibly, copious amounts of hallucinogens and other intoxicants, hence, the 'as soon as pain allows', bizzo.

I've dived way deeper into the Jungian interpretation of the song than I intended (but I s'pose it's appropriate, considering the album is choc full of it) and I wanted to also quickly support jimmy11:11's theory on 11:11 and Lightworkers.  The reference stinks of Tool, who take a concept (like Jung's Anima), put their own spin on it (as they rightly should), and then layer it, or relate it to other theories, such as 11:11.  Observe Keenan's battle with his Shadow (another Jung concept) and how Tool combines this with theories on genetic evolution/perfection (46&2 chromosomes, as opposed to the normal 42&2, or whatever it is).  It's the 'wheels within wheels' that Frank Herbert so loves, and which makes Dune (among his other books) such interesting reads, and gets them into the recommended reading list by the band.

Once I send this, i'm going to have another quick look at: greatdreams.com/…, where jimmy11:11's quote came from.  I know it's crackpot gobbledygook, but, like we're asked in aenema, "show you can read between the lines."

I can't believe this hasn't been updated since the new album (10,000 Days), but I think I got this figured out.  I can't claim to know all about this song, but this should at least clear up some stuff (this also isn't original, as I've read it other places, but keep an open and skeptical mind).

Maynard was born April 17, 1964.When he was 11, it was 1975/76.  This means he is now 42 years old. 10,000 days is equal to 27 years and some-odd days.  His mother had a stroke in 1976, and died in 2003.  This period of time is equal to 27 years, or 10,000 days.

So in other words, when Maynard was 11, his mother had a stroke, leaving her paralyzed for the rest of her life (being 27 years, 10,000 days).  The song jimmy is about his mother having a stroke, Judith is about her unwaivering support in God despite those around her and her position, and Wings for Marie/10,000 Days is I guess more or less a eulogy.

comment_120:
Maynardâs mother suffered a crippling stroke in 1975 or 1976, presumably when he was eleven years old. Born James Herbert Keenan on April 17, 1964, Maynardâs child name was probably Jimmy.
K is the eleventh letter of the alphabet. Ketamine was an inspiration to Maynard, especially on this album. For proof, read the fourth inside page of the liner notes describing (without naming) K as a dissociative anesthetic used for surgery on different species of baboons or monkeys. Anyone who has experienced the âemergent stateâ of conscious anesthesia on K will draw a distinct psychosomatic connection with the lyrics to the left. K users call the drug state âbeing stuckâ or âbeing in a hole,â because the profound detachment promotes stillness, yet within the sinking depth of the conscious dream state, the mind is wide awake, experiencing a state that is more psychedelic than anesthetic. K is very reflective, often causing the user to put together information about his/her past in a profound way (showing me where it all began). Movements and sounds take on a profound, extended meaning and a sense of ritualism.
In the reflective state of Ketamine it seems that Maynard recognized an inner calling that has been subconsciously urging him to return to and re-inspect aspects of his difficult childhood. He realized that this voice was a part of himself that he had disconnected from: Jimmy, the eleven year old. Perhaps one reason Maynard rejected his past self was the religious view that eleven-year-old held. Jimmy held a light (a holy view of the world) that is no longer the light that Maynard holds (Maynard killed that light).
The adult Maynard has a new understanding of the world, a new light to hold. K is especially powerful in that kind of transformation. The experience feels the same each time, yet it is hard to remember it explicitly, once sober. It is like coming home to an elusive but familiar place every time. It is a comfortable, still, quiet place where memories converge and reunite. It feels like you are tapping into a place that has always been there, and that will always be there for you, like home.
Emboldened to confront and accept his childhood, he can heal, reunite with his past, and move on. âJimmyâ is probably a song about that, as most carefully analysts have concluded, but they miss the parallel to the drug that caused it to happen. This omission is understandable, because not many people have tried K, and also for that reason many will reject this Ketamine analysis of the song. My answer is this: look at the liner notes, try the drug, and listen to the song again. To not acknowledge K is to not fully understand Tool. âPrying open my third eyeâ also refers to using K or similar drugs to attain a visionary state of projected mind.
